Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this proposal is homology of finite random simplicial complexes and Betti numbers of these complexes. Specifically, the investigator proposes methods based on combinatorial Hodge's theory to develop estimators for Betti numbers and other topological invariants (such as the Euler characteristic) of finite random complexes. As a direct outcome investigator expects to address questions in the theory of coverage processes, random sensor networks and the theory of random sets. An example of a problem the project will address is estimates for probability of complete coverage for finite coverage processes on closed Riemannian manifolds. This question has been precisely answered only in small number cases, such as the circle, the 2-sphere and very recently in the case of the sphere of arbitrary dimension. By studying a random nerve and Betti numbers associated to the random cover of a coverage process, the investigator seeks to provide insight into to this and related problems in the field. A long term goal of this project is development of a homology theory for (compact) random subsets of a metric space via an analog of a Cech construction adapted to the random setting. An advantage of this approach is reduction of a problem (of e.g. Betti number determination) to the finite probability space, where known numerical techniques can be used to estimate distributions of Betti numbers, and consequently address algorithmic questions involving complete coverage probability, distribution of number of clumps and other topological characteristics of random sets.

There are several practical outcomes expected of this project; one of them is novel coverage criteria for stochastic sensor networks. To elucidate, the reader should imagine that a swarm of cheap sensors is spread over a region in space. Sensors broadcast their unique IDs and have no capabilities to locate themselves (no GPS!) but only are able to determine if a different sensor or a "threat" appears in their neighborhood. The sensors communicate with a central processing node which reads their information via their IDs, the IDs of the neighboring nodes, and potential threats within the region to be secured. Additionally, we may assume that sensors and communication channels have stochastic features, that is, operate correctly only with a given probability or, for example, the sensors are mobile and appear and disappear from each other's sensing range. Under such constraints the methods developed in this project will provide new and effective criteria to determine the probability that the region is secure (i.e., covered by sensors). These criteria will be suitable for implementation in the central processing node as a threat detection algorithm. The further outcome of the proposed project will yield new qualitative approaches to probabilistic models of dust or powder particles, systems of water droplets and other similar processes, where one often is interested in features such as probability of cluster formation or connectivity, which are essential characteristics of these physical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theme of this project concerned the idea of homology for random simplicial complexes with applications in the areas such as sensor networks, random set theory and coverage processes. The PI has used the awarded funding in three ways:

Goal (A) development of the theory of random complexes and coverage processes as described in the proposal.
Goal (B) support for the basic PI’s research in the area of low dimensional and geometric topology.
Goal (C) investigation of research problems relevant to Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) and development of new ideas in genomics and metagenomics.

The broader impacts of the proposal concerned the following goals.

Goal (D) Training of graduate and undergraduate students.
Goal (E) Enhancement of research activity in the area of topology and geometry at Tulane University.

Major accomplishments achieved.

Under Goal (A). A study of topological features of higher dimensional random complexes is a relatively uncharted field of mathematics and a few results are available. From the perspective of applications, a firm understanding of random topological features (such as clustering or dimension) has fundamental consequences in areas such as sensor coverage problems, map reconstruction, and essentially any applied discipline which relies on the tools of classical data analysis. For illustration purposes consider the following setup, imagine a road network is a large city and objects (we will further call the nodes) moving along the network (e.g. vehicles or people). Presently, many nodes (e.g. taxi cabs) are equipped with sensors, such as web cameras which are connected to the internet. in addition, there are fixed points in the city where stationary cameras are installed. Assuming the nodes do not know their position but can communicate what they see (i.e. sensor information) to a central server (including information about other nodes within their sensing range) one may wish to compute a probability that the road network is covered, namely that the nodes sensing range covers the entire road network. The abstract problem of finding a complete coverage probability by any random coverage process has a long history and was successfully addressed only in a limited number of cases (for instance random arcs on the circle). The main achievement of this project, under Goal (A), is a formulation of the complete coverage problem in the language of random topological features and finding an explicit formula for the complete coverage probability in terms of a distribution of the underlying nerve complex.  This novel approach also yields explicit estimates for the complete coverage probability and can be applied to practical problems, such as the road network problem described before.

Under Goal (C). The traditional methods for comparison and feature extraction from biological sequences (such as DNA or protein sequences) are based on the alignment algorithms.  Such algorithms compute a certain similarity measure or distance between the sequences. Subsequently, other methods, such as the phylogenetic tree analysis, provide insights into the hierarchical relationships among genomes and organisms. Inspired by DTRA’s Challenges, the PI in collaboration with students at Tulane proposed a new approach for quantifying data contained in the biological sequences. This method uses powerful tools from algebraic topology and currently is subject to further development. The main idea of the method can be summarized as follows. Given a sequence of letters over an alphabet (for instance the alphabet {A, C, G, T} is used for DNA sequences) we assign a topological space to the sequence. Topological spaces are just nothing but, broadly understood, shapes such as the ones shown on Figure 1.  Thanks to the idea of a topological space assignment to a biological sequence, we may now think about a shape of the biological sequence. Shapes can be quantified using various parameters. For instance, Betti numbers βk (from algebraic topology) are well known characteristics of shapes (see Figure 1 for Betti numbers of the pictured shapes). The following question was the main focus of the proposed approach:

How much the shape of a biological sequence (e.g. its Betti numbers) reflect its function?

To effectively address this question the PI (in collaboration with Tulane students) proposed, a statistical method of analyzing long sequences by sampling fixed size subsequences, and computing mean vectors of Betti numbers. This method was subsequently applied to the genomic sequences of the selected 6–genera of the common bacteria: Rickettsia, Helicobacter, Streptococcus, Campylobacter. Our numerical analysis revealed two significant Betti numbers relevant for cluster analysis of the above genera. The plot of Figure 2 shows a fairly good clustering of the analyzed genera, where Chlamydophila and Streptococcus are separated and the pairs Francisella– Rickettsia and Campylobacter–Helicobacter are overlapping. The biological literature on the subject explains the overlaps as associated with a similar biological function. This provides a solid evidence that our topological method may provide a useful alternative to the existing methods in genomic sequence analysis.
